note.para: This section describes some concepts that will be valid for all implementations of &HttpClient; but will also focus on some details that, at this time, pertain only to the sole implementation of this interface, &DefaultHttpClient; - meaning that this behavior can change in a different special-purpose implementation.

sect2.title: Handling execution requests
sect2.para: &DefaultHttpClient; deals with concurrent requests using a producer-consumer approach. Whenever a thread calls execute(), this implementation will generate a context object that will associate the three elements necessary to each request:

listitem.para: &HttpResponseProcessor;: the handler of the HTTP response, in case one is received
&HttpRequestFuture;: the future that will be unlocked once this request is completed

sect2.para: The aggregator of these elements is a &HttpRequestContext;. Once generated, this context is then fed to a BlockingQueue. This effectively makes every caller of execute() a producer.

On the other side of the BlockingQueue lies an internal event processing thread. The job of this thread is to process multiple types of events, generated at the left and right of &HttpClient;:
EXECUTE_REQUEST: generated when producers submit new requests. Handling this event does not mean that the request will immediately be executed.
REQUEST_COMPLETE: generated by &HttpConnection;s when a request completes.
CONNECTION_OPEN: generated by the &HttpConnection;s, to signal a new connection is open and ready to perform requests.
CONNECTION_CLOSED: generated by the &HttpConnection;s when a connection closes, either unexpectedly or gracefully (doesn't really matter for the &DefaultHttpClient;).
CONNECTION_FAILED: generated by the &HttpConnection;s when a connection to a given host fails to establish.

listitem.para: When a &HttpRequestContext; is created (when execute() is called on the &HttpClient;), it's wrapped in a EXECUTE_REQUEST event and put into the BlockingQueue.

The event processor will pick this event and feed it to a &HostContext;. The &HostContext; is a delegate contains, at every given moment, the number of connections open to that host, the number of connections opening and the requests queued for that host.

Assuming this is the first request, no connection is open so the &HostContext; will signal back to the event processor that a new connection needs to be opened. At the same time it queues this request, but this time, it queues it on the specific &HostContext; it belongs to. All requests will eventuall pass from the event queue (wrapped in events, or &HttpClientEvent;) to the &HostContext; queue. This ensures that all request are executed in the exact same order they are submitted.
Which doesn't necessarily mean that it will complete before another request, but that's a whole different story.

When this connection finally opens - under the form of a &HttpConnection; - it fires up a CONNECTION_OPEN event. When the event processor handles this event it will then drain the &HostContext; queue into the recently open connection.

Every time a REQUEST_COMPLETE is handled by the event processor, it will query the appropriate &HostContext; and drain any pending requests, one at a time, for each available &HttpConnection;. &HttpConnection;s are considered available when they are connected and not executing (sending and/or waiting for response) any requests.

sect1.title: Summary
sect1.para: In this chapter we covered how &DefaultHttpClient; works internally and how it interacts both with the producers and the other components of &hotpotato;. This should provide you with a better understanding on why some of the configuration parameters affect &hotpotato;'s functioning they way they do.
